title: As of 1 July 2018, how many manufacturers will hold permits for driverless testing of autonomous vehicles in California?
preds: Last business day and no sign of anything on the page where presumably this info would show up [1], nor in the news. [1] https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/auto
Updating from 95/5/0/0/0 (yesterday's forecast). Only 2 business days to go.
Updating from 90/10/0/0/0 due to passage of time.

Updating from 80/20/0/0/0. No permit holders as of today, 22 June 2018 [1]. Only five weekdays before question closes. I don't think they issue these permits over the weekend. [1] https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/auto
Numbers of potential candidates and their technical maturities.
Shifting toward no because there's not much time left.
With two weeks to go, I think this question is going to be a wash due to bureaucratic inertia. Just trying to save my long-term Brier score at this point.

A bit late to the party, but I will give it a shot. So far only two applications according to [1] so I am guessing chance of >3 is close to nil.  The DMV has been able to approve applications since 30 days after April 2 [2] and Waymo applied in April so supposedly their application should be relatively far along. However, it is common to underestimate public agency processes, which is one of the reasons I am leaning toward 0. California doesn't want to let AZ take business away [3], but at the same time I doubt there is serious impetus for tech companies to suddenly start moving to AZ over this. The timeline for the question is quite short considering that regulators are dealing with a new and potentially incident-causing technology. [1] https://www.kqed.org/news/11671752/regulators-ok-test-of-driverless-passenger-service-on-california-roads
[2] https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/auto
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/26/technology/driverless-cars-california-rules.html

Seventeen days to go and as far as I can tell, no permits have been issued. The news I found said one company's application got rejected on 12 Apr due to insufficient info, and Waymo's was accepted (meaning they'll look at it) around 25 Apr [1]. This is the first time such an application is evaluated; there's presumably little process in place, the bureaucracy has no experience handling this type of request. There aren't any deadlines either. So as a baseline we should guess this will take very long. The much simpler processes of obtaining various immigration documents take several months each. Now let's look at incentives. Arizona has already allowed anyone to do anything with driverless cars, as far as I can tell. If I am a regulator, I feel I'd wait to see how that goes for a while, before giving my approval. I stand to lose if I give approval and then people get killed. And I stand to gain nothing by approving quickly. (Or so it seems to me.) So another reason to delay. [1] http://www.consumerwatchdog.org/privacy-technology/consumer-watchdog-calls-dmv-open-robot-car-application-process-public-after
Shifting toward no because there are only three weeks left. Still possible California could announce a permit but it seems unlikely.

It's been 1 month and 3 weeks since Waymo applied and they still haven't gotten their permit - because there is no limit on how long the state can take to decide if they're going to grant or deny the permit.  With 3.5 weeks to go I'm dropping my 100% 1-3 prediction significantly so that I don't completely destroy my score.  I still think Waymo will have their permit granted, but unfortunately not by the deadline.
Updating in favour of small number; this reflects China's move to offer similar licenses.
Bringing my probabilities closer to zero. I don't think anyone else has applied and at this point the Cali DMV has just over 30 days to meet GJP's deadline.

WoC0.86 for 1 to 3 based on 124 bets from 87 of us. Zero is only 6% and 4 to 6 is 11%.  So moving down towards zero. Maybe the Ca DMV will announce that Waymo passes before July 1st. Surely it only takes 30 to 60 days to make a decision? OK so it's the DMV, do we double it? If Google put it in on April, then it's going to cut it very close. Will suck if it's July 2nd.
No idea if resolution by July 1 but did see the Waymo Jaguars and Volvos at Google I/O (plus a Peterbilt transport). The cars looked ready for street usage.
Hold” is a pretty tight resolution criteria. I’m thinking the two that have so far will probably be it.

Google's application has seen no progressive.  I see no news as an increasing odds that California is going to take a lot of time to make sure they aren't making a potential mistake.  Who knows how much data they need to comb through and how many legal advisors they need to consult.

Five weeks left. How will we know if and when someone is approved? I'm seeing no news on this since California announced the application process in April. Not many companies interested: https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/articles/2018-04-27/california-companies-slow-to-seek-fully-driverless-car-approval Waymo's application was complete and ready for review in April: http://www.consumerwatchdog.org/privacy-technology/consumer-watchdog-calls-dmv-open-robot-car-application-process-public-after
I will bet on Waymo, GM and maybe Apple.

The California DMV had predicted they'd be ready for automakers to start testing driverless cars on public roads in April, and started accepting applications on the 2nd of the month. The new rules also allow testing vehicles without steering wheels, foot pedals and mirrors. Waymo is actually the second company to apply for driverless testing in California. The DMV confirmed to the San Francisco Chronicle that two have submitted appropriate paperwork (the first applied earlier this month), but declined to identify either.
https://www.engadget.com/2018/04/13/waymo-applies-fully-driverless-car-tests-california/
Waymo seems to have one and I don't see anyone else being confident enough to dismiss the backup driver

Waymo (Google) is one of two companies that have applied. Perhaps others have since applied - difficult to find much info. @D_L_Parks may have been first to mention Waymo. Quote from Waymo:
[Waymo] is the only company in the world to have fully driverless vehicles on public roads today.
https://simpsonlawgroup.com/blog/waymo-applies-california-dmv-test-autonomous-cars-without-back-driver/
Simply a subjective balance of what I see as a growing capability (balanced against the realistic capability limitations) versus structural restrictions.
Updating slightly in favour of a small (1-3) nr of licenses.

Only 2 have applied so far (out of 50+ on the with driver permit). Still time to apply (10 days review to see if application is complete, no timeline given for this permit but previous permit, the depart. aimed to get back within 30 days, but more complexity in demonstrating meeting legal requirements for this permit). There is time for others to apply but the other manufacturers would be waiting for before filling (in tech there's a big benefit to being first) so the fact that they didn't register for a permit early on may be telling of intentions over the next few months. 
Uber crash seems to have made some manufacturers more cautious (http://abc7news.com/automotive/autonomous-car-makers-riding-the-brakes-on-ca-driverless-test-permits/3294849/). But many manufacturers have invested a lot in the tech (https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21737418-driverless-vehicles-will-change-world-just-cars-did-them-what-went-wrong). It may be a matter of the other manufacturers (than the 2 that have applied) pausing and re-evaluating strategy which may take longer than before July.
Two companies have applied for permits but the California DMV has an unlimited amount of time to approve or deny applications.

I am very interested in autonomous cars and the safety and flexibility that it will bring to our world. According to a quick google search, as of about March 2018 about 52 companies have permits to test driver-less cars with a driver currently in California.

Any ideas about this list of over 50+ companies with a permit? https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6394923553052979200 I wonder how many of these involve that drivers must remain in the car.

Spreading probability and reviewing of number of existing approvals. Big question is what is meant by 'manufacturer' - only recognised auto manufacturer (toyota, ford) or also including tech companies (Google, Apple) and/or component manufacturers (Bosch, Intel) and/or start-ups focused on autonomous tech.

There are at least 18-20 companies already testing autonomous vehicles, including software companies, car companies and other component manufacturers. Due to the competitive nature of the tech industry, none will want to be left behind the development curve

2 applicants so far and no one knows how long the approval process will take. To date (20 April), only two companies have applied for such permits and presently, the other company remains anonymous. The DMV has an indefinite timeline to approve or deny permit requests. - http://www.automotive-fleet.com/news/story/2018/04/waymo-applies-to-test-driverless-cars-on-california-roads.aspx
Uber and Tesla induced deaths will force decision makers to reassess permits, possibly causing more stringent restrictions to enter.
Given the crash there may be no applications actually approved.

The timeline is very short; the two applications are pending and the space is still plagued by the uncertainty from the last accidents. It is not unlikely though for at least one license to be accepted to press for regulatory due diligence.

Two applications so far. "Indefinite timeline to approve or deny requests." 10 weeks left. Who are the possible applicants during that timeframe?
Waymo
GM
Voyage
Drive.ai
Zoox
Uber
Apple
Tesla (not likely)
Embark (not likely) Many companies that are testing self-driving cars are doing it in Europe or Asia, not California.

Two companies have applied.  One is Waymo .   It seems its application was incomplete. 
https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/04/13/waymo-applies-to-test-driverless-cars-on-california-streets/ The other is almost certainly GM, although it could be the taxi ride sharing service.  IMO,  California pushed through the rules for driverless, after Waymo pulled half its fleet to Arizona to do driverless testing.  Waymo will be able to use the results of AZ testing to satisfy regulators in CA.  IMO California wants to be the state to be the bellwhether on driverless testing.  In addition, Waymo has been very smartr on its application.  Its initial permit is merely for roads around its campus with a maximum speed of 6.5 mph.   AZ has no rules on this - and CA was losing its position.   Its going to get approved.  The question is .. when. 
Waymo has stopped its testing in AZ for now.   And the publicity for Waymo is terrible  Still, approving the testing for Waymo around its campus offers huge advantages for Waymo - much quicker turn cycles on code revision, easier trouble shooting.  When people want things to get done - they do...
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/26/technology/driverless-cars-california-rules.html Also interesting: Diane Feinstein pushed through federal regulations opposing driverless testing. 
State of California one month later pushed back - and approved it.  More interesting news:  Feinstein gets huge donations from:  Elon Musk.  Why would Elon want to slow down autonomous testing mmmm? 
Could it be because his av product isn't ready yet?...

Comes down to pragmatism, they won't want to cede any more ground to China. Just that this timeline is a bit short, would be at 7 or so if it was 2021, or 5 in 2020, but July this year is just cutting it close.  The negative publicity of Tesla and Uber crashes and fatalities will put a heavy ceiling on it.  Maybe GM Cruise will go first. Perhaps Google's Waymo. Maybe NVIDIA.   Or one of the 52 here https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/permit. Not sure how many actually have driverless cars ready.  Who will apply first? Will they get approved? Would be funny if Ford Argo did.  Economist article paywalled, free link http://archive.is/upbNO

Maybe not the greatest timing given Nevada and Tesla incidents (which had people in car). Per the article, you may not want to be viewed as rushing in... second article - one company (not identified) has applied but not granted (until at least May)
http://abc7news.com/automotive/autonomous-car-makers-riding-the-brakes-on-ca-driverless-test-permits/3294849/
https://sf.curbed.com/2018/4/3/17193730/driverless-car-autonomous-permits-california-uber-dmv
